definition: classifier for an activity, taken in its entirety (tirade of abuse, stint of music playing, bout of drinking etc)
to go through/to know well/(suffix) expert/to connect/to communicate/open/to clear/classifier for letters, telegrams, phone calls etc

pinyin: e4 xing4 tong1 huo4 peng2 zhang4

sentences.english: It's a classic case of cost-push inflation.
sentences.chinese: 這是典型的成本推動的通貨膨脹。

sentences.english: Traditional schoolbook says inflation will cause devaluation.
sentences.chinese: 傳統的教科書說通貨膨脹將導致貨幣貶值。

sentences.english: Sometimes inflation may rise from causes dissociated from money.
sentences.chinese: 有時候通貨膨脹可能由興錢無關的原因引起。

sentences.english: Instead, inflation is turning out to be a potentially thornier problem.
sentences.chinese: 然而現在通貨膨脹正在變成一個更嚴峻的潛在問題。

sentences.english: But one of the side effects of all that liquidity in the markets was inflation.
sentences.chinese: 但是，市場流動性所帶來的另一個效果就是通貨膨脹。
經濟有通貨膨脹的趨勢。
通貨膨脹使物價節節上漲。

sentences.english: What do investors do when the government sounds a warning about inflation?
sentences.chinese: 政府對通貨膨脹發出警告之際，投資者該怎麼做？

sentences.english: If credit growth roars on, the Chinese central bank will have a lot of trouble controlling inflation.
sentences.chinese: 如果信貸持續增加，央行控制通貨膨脹將步履維艱。

sentences.english: China's leaders say fighting rising inflation is also a priority.
sentences.chinese: 中國領導人稱，抑止通貨膨脹也是頭等大事。

sentences.english: Printing money will eventually lead to a higher price level or inflation.
sentences.chinese: 印刷貨幣會造成價格水平上漲或者通貨膨脹。

sentences.english: Already, Mr. Tedford says, inflation is apparent.
sentences.chinese: 泰得福德說，通貨膨脹勢頭已經顯而易見。

sentences.english: You caused all these harm and trouble and inflation.
sentences.chinese: 是政府造成了所有這些傷害和麻煩和通貨膨脹。

sentences.english: As a result, low-risk investments often yield below-inflation returns.
sentences.chinese: 結果是，低風險的投資者常常收益低於通貨膨脹。

sentences.english: EFFORTS to curb inflation in China are having some painful side-effects.
sentences.chinese: 中國抑制通貨膨脹的措施正在引起一些副作用。

definition: to undulate/to fluctuate/wave motion/rise and fall
hook (on which to hang sth)/to couple/to link together/to establish contact with/hook/coupling links (e.g. between two railway coaches)
to intensify/to sharpen/to accelerate/to aggravate/to exacerbate/to embitter
